htmlEmbed:
Archive of Our Own Survived a Cyberattack, But Will It Survive Congress?Cond√© Nast7/27/2023

Archive of Our Own (AO3), a fanfic site loved by young LGBTQ+ people, was compromised by hackers. But the Kids Online Safety Act (KOSA) is the real threat.

politics, internet, transgender rights, trans, lgbtq rights, lgbtq youth, community, social media, fandom, u.s. government, congress, politics op-ed, textbelowcentergridwidth, web, tagsRead

        </script><script type="text/javascript">window.cns = window.cns || {}; window.cns.pageContext = {"channel":"news-and-politics","content":{"copyCount":1347,"imageCount":0,"embedCount":0,"ratio":0,"midContentCadence":500},"contentType":"article","experiments":{},"keywords":{"copilotid":["64beecd74d3469f26f73fc22"],"platform":["verso"],"tags":["news-and-politics","internet","transgender-rights","trans","lgbtq-rights","lgbtq-youth","community","social-media","fandom","us-government","congress","politics-op-ed","article-settings","contentheader","variation","textbelowcentergridwidth"]},"server":"production","slug":"kids-online-safety-act-lgbtq-youth","subChannel":"","subSubChannel":"","templateType":"mt_article_two_column"};</script><link rel="preconnect" href="https://ads-static.conde.digital"/><script id="ads-v6" src="https://ads-static.conde.digital/production/cns/builds/teen-vogue/v6.js" async=""></script><script type="application/ld+json">{"@context":"http://schema.org","@type":"NewsArticle","articleBody":"One day in mid-July, the revered fan fiction site Archive of Our Own (AO3), a bottomless repository for stories set in thousands of fictional worlds, suddenly went dark. AO3 was inaccessible for more than 24 hours. The volunteer-run site, we later learned, had been targeted by cyberattackers who reportedly had religious and political motivations for aiming to take down the site.\nI‚Äôve been an AO3 reader for over 10 years, and this isn‚Äôt the first outage I‚Äôve experienced. But this one felt different. Not only was it longer than usual, it was apparently prompted, in part, by hatred for queer people.\nA day later, AO3 was back online, but concerns have lingered: What would happen if fan communities, especially queer fandoms that are lifelines for young LGBTQ+ people, ceased to exist? And it turns out, one of the most worrisome threats facing sites like AO3 isn‚Äôt a small outfit of cyberattackers, it‚Äôs the United States government.\nRight now there are a handful of bills being rushed through Congress in the 11th hour before August recess that could permanently damage the ability of AO3 to reach its audience. The main threat is the Kids Online Safety Act (KOSA). Framed as ‚Äúprotecting children,‚Äù KOSA creates a ‚Äúduty of care‚Äù that requires apps and websites to ‚Äúprevent and mitigate‚Äù harms to children, like anxiety and depression, their products might cause. If the app or website doesn‚Äôt take steps to mitigate those harms, usually through removing content, it can be held liable.\nProtecting children from harmful content with Big Tech taking the fall may sound great, until you consider who will have the power to decide what content is harmful ‚Äî and, therefore, what content is removed. KOSA authorizes state attorneys general to be the ultimate arbiters of what is good or bad for kids. If a state attorney general asserts that information about gender-affirming care or abortion care could cause a child depression or anxiety, they could sue an app or website for not removing that content.\nTo prevent that liability, the app or website could proactively remove content that a conservative attorney general might think is bad for kids. But a lot of attorneys general think legitimate content is bad for kids.\nI live in Texas, where our attorney general, Ken Paxton, has called gender-affirming health care child abuse. Some Texas lawmakers want to make it illegal for abortion funds to have websites. The school district I grew up in is currently under investigation by the ACLU for discriminating against trans students. My teacher friends approach civil rights lessons with anxiety, fearful of triggering outraged reactions from legislators and parents. We don‚Äôt live in a country where there is a consensus about what is harmful to children, so how could the government determine what‚Äôs appropriate for every kid?\nPeople who are afraid of social media‚Äôs impact on kids, I've noticed, often quote a recent advisory on the topic from the surgeon general as evidence that kids should not have access to information online. But the most under-cited part of that report is actually the most important: There is a whole section that acknowledges LGBTQ+ youth actually have better outcomes when they have access to social media and online communities.\nSimply put, queer and trans kids are happier and healthier when they have access to supportive online groups, like the fandom communities I found through fan fiction published on AO3. Last year, I attended the wedding of a friend I met in a comments section while gushing about our shared favorite fan fiction. We talked every day for years, and then I finally got to meet her in person, the day before she married the person she loved. Two other friends from that same community are married to each other now, and others have moved across the country to live together. All of us are queer and, in our teen years, had turned to fandom as a refuge, yearning for more inclusive stories and supportive communities we didn‚Äôt have in our day-to-day lives.\nKOSA‚Äôs champions claim the amended bill, which was tweaked after vocal opposition, represents no threat to queer people and online communities like mine, but those of us who lived through SESTA/FOSTA‚Äôs impact on sex education, sex workers, and online content know that just isn‚Äôt true. (And activists say the changes aren‚Äôt enough.) SESTA/FOSTA, legislation that was supposed to help fight sex trafficking, not only failed to prevent trafficking and help survivors, as research has shown, it decimated online communities and censored sex education content along the way. Much of this content was information many only had access to online, in places like Tumblr, because of conservative parents and abstinence-only sex education we received at school.\nLike SESTA/FOSTA, KOSA creates the aforementioned duty of care for social media companies, giving state attorneys general the power to sue sites like Instagram or Twitter if they put up content they deem ‚Äúharmful‚Äù for kids and teens. With SESTA/FOSTA, we saw that tech companies preferred to shut down already-policed content about reproductive justice, LGBTQ+ identities, and sex education than risk a lawsuit.\nKOSA‚Äôs supporters might want to ignore the fact that it‚Äôs a censorship bill in disguise, but the Heritage Foundation is saying the quiet part out loud. The hard-line conservative organization has openly said KOSA will help them censor the content conservatives don‚Äôt want young people to have access to.\nThe question is: Are Democrats going to hand them the keys to the kingdom? We have a choice in whether we fall for the rhetoric about kids' ‚Äúsafety‚Äù bills and watch in horror as the Ken Paxtons of the world weaponize them against our rights or fight KOSA with everything we‚Äôve got, pushing for better tech bills that would actually protect young people from the harms of Big Tech.\nIf Congress wants to hold tech companies liable, there‚Äôs a ton of low-hanging fruit. The United States is embarrassingly behind in data-privacy protections. That means that right now, it‚Äôs profitable for tech companies to spy on kids and teens and micro-target them with addictive and damaging content. If it wasn‚Äôt profitable, they would be pressured to move on to different, less harmful business models. There are other simpler options too: We could pass legislation to curb algorithmic harm, targeted advertising, and design features like endless scrolling.\nIn my day job, I‚Äôm a digital rights organizer who has been working against KOSA for months. I talk to young people daily who are scared about the future of their online communities. Sure, fandom is partly about reading silly little stories written by our friends, but it represents so much more. When we can‚Äôt come out at home, we can lead safer, anonymous lives online. When queer stories have been physically pulled from our library shelves, we can see ourselves in digital fiction written by people like us, for us. The panic about AO3 is not just about losing fan works, but about losing a lifeline in the midst of an onslaught of bigoted legislation.\nWhen I meet KOSA supporters who claim to be ‚Äúprotecting the children,‚Äù I have to ask: Which children are we talking about? Because the children I know, the teenagers who email me every day with worries about KOSA, they live in fear of the future KOSA would create. I‚Äôll be damned if their future is an internet where the people who want to harm them most have the power to cut them off from their loved ones ‚Äî¬†even if those communities are found through a screen.\nStay up-to-date with the politics team. Sign up for the Teen Vogue Take","isBasedOn":"https://www.teenvogue.com/story/kids-online-safety-act-lgbtq-youth","articleSection":"politics","author":[{"@type":"Person","name":"Sarah Philips","sameAs":"https://www.teenvogue.com/contributor/sarah-philips"}],"dateModified":"2023-07-27T07:27:46.360-04:00","datePublished":"2023-07-27T07:27:46.360-04:00","headline":"Archive of Our Own Survived a Cyberattack, But Will It Survive Congress?","image":["https://assets.teenvogue.com/photos/64c196fc898df4db96ac3415/16:9/w_2992,h_1683,c_limit/GettyImages-91844831.jpg","https://assets.teenvogue.com/photos/64c196fc898df4db96ac3415/4:3/w_3000,h_2250,c_limit/GettyImages-91844831.jpg","https://assets.teenvogue.com/photos/64c196fc898df4db96ac3415/1:1/w_2260,h_2260,c_limit/GettyImages-91844831.jpg"],"keywords":["politics","internet","transgender rights","trans","lgbtq rights","lgbtq youth","community","social media","fandom","u.s. government","congress","politics op-ed","textbelowcentergridwidth","web"],"thumbnailUrl":"https://assets.teenvogue.com/photos/64c196fc898df4db96ac3415/3:2/w_3000,h_2000,c_limit/GettyImages-91844831.jpg","url":"https://www.teenvogue.com/story/kids-online-safety-act-lgbtq-youth","isPartOf":{"@type":"CreativeWork","name":"Teen Vogue"},"isAccessibleForFree":true,"alternativeHeadline":"Archive of Our Own (AO3), a fanfic site loved by young LGBTQ+ people, was compromised by hackers. data-attribute-verso-pattern="article-body" class="ArticlePageContentBackGround-cNiFNN kJkLmH article-body__content"><div class="ArticlePageChunksContent-etcMtP bwyLBj"><div data-testid="ArticlePageChunks" class="ArticlePageChunks-fLyCVG eOdfIs"><div class="GridWrapper-cAzTTK kHBDeH grid grid-margins grid-items-2 ArticlePageChunksGrid-hfxaau bjczjj grid-layout--adrail narrow wide-adrail"><div class="GridItem-buujkM stRKV grid--item grid-layout__content"><div class="BodyWrapper-kufPGa XtZXd body body__container article__body" data-journey-hook="client-content" data-testid="BodyWrapper"><div class="body__inner-container"><p>One day in mid-July, the <a href="https://www.theverge.com/2022/8/15/23200176/history-of-ao3-archive-of-our-own-fanfiction">revered</a> fan fiction site Archive of Our Own (AO3), a bottomless repository for stories set in thousands of fictional worlds, suddenly <a href="https://www.theverge.com/2023/7/11/23790860/ao3-fanfiction-archive-down-outage-ddos-attacks">went dark</a>. AO3 was inaccessible for more than 24 hours. The volunteer-run site, we later learned, had been targeted by cyberattackers who <a data-offer-url="https://twitter.com/AO3_Status/status/1678513922649751555?s=20" class="external-link" data-event-click="{"element":"ExternalLink","outgoingURL":"https://twitter.com/AO3_Status/status/1678513922649751555?s=20"}" href="https://twitter.com/AO3_Status/status/1678513922649751555?s=20" rel="nofollow noopener" target="_blank">reportedly</a> had religious and political motivations for aiming to take down the site.¬†</p><p>I‚Äôve been an AO3 reader for over 10 years, and this isn‚Äôt the first outage I‚Äôve experienced. But this one felt different. Not only was it longer than usual, it was apparently prompted, in part, by hatred for queer people.¬†</p><div><div class="ConsumerMarketingUnitThemedWrapper-iUTMTf jssHut consumer-marketing-unit consumer-marketing-unit--article-mid-content" role="presentation" aria-hidden="true"><div class="consumer-marketing-unit__slot consumer-marketing-unit__slot--article-mid-content consumer-marketing-unit__slot--in-content"></div><div class="journey-unit"></div></div></div><p>A day later, AO3 was back online, but concerns have lingered: What would happen if fan communities, especially queer fandoms that are lifelines for young LGBTQ+ people, ceased to exist? And it turns out, one of the most worrisome threats facing sites like AO3 isn‚Äôt a small outfit of cyberattackers, it‚Äôs the United States government.</p><div class="Container-bkChBi byNLHx"></div><p>Right now there are a <a href="https://www.theverge.com/2023/5/5/23712443/kosa-earn-it-coppa-child-privacy-data-tiktok-blackburn-blumenthal">handful</a> of bills being rushed through Congress in the 11th hour before August recess that could permanently damage the ability of AO3 to reach its audience. The main threat is the <a href="https://www.congress.gov/bill/118th-congress/senate-bill/1409">Kids Online Safety Act (KOSA)</a>. Framed as ‚Äúprotecting children,‚Äù KOSA creates a ‚Äúduty of care‚Äù that requires apps and websites to ‚Äúprevent and mitigate‚Äù harms to children, like anxiety and depression, their products might cause. If the app or website doesn‚Äôt take steps to mitigate those harms, usually through removing content, it can be held liable.</p><div class="AdWrapper-dQtivb fZrssQ ad ad--in-content"><div class="ad__slot ad__slot--in-content" data-node-id="m3uf9"></div></div><p>Protecting children from harmful content with Big Tech taking the fall may sound great, until you consider <a href="https://jezebel.com/19-republican-attorneys-general-want-police-to-investig-1850648742">who</a> will have the power to decide what content is harmful ‚Äî and, therefore, what content is removed. KOSA authorizes state attorneys general to be the ultimate arbiters of what is good or bad for kids. If a state attorney general asserts that information about gender-affirming care or abortion care could cause a child depression or anxiety, they could sue an app or website for not removing that content.¬†</p><div data-attr-viewport-monitor="inline-recirc" class="inline-recirc-wrapper inline-recirc-observer-target-1 viewport-monitor-anchor"></div><p>To prevent that liability, the app or website could proactively remove content that a conservative attorney general might think is bad for kids. But a lot of attorneys general think legitimate content is bad for kids.</p><p>I live in Texas, where our attorney general, Ken Paxton, has <a href="https://apnews.com/article/texas-transgender-hospital-investigation-greg-abbott-dce466dcaa7be541c009a2fdc0b4a286">called</a> gender-affirming health care child abuse. Some Texas lawmakers want to make it illegal for abortion funds <a href="https://www.theverge.com/2023/3/3/23622346/texas-bill-block-isp-access-abortion">to have websites</a>. The school district I grew up in <a href="https://www.texastribune.org/2022/11/22/aclu-civil-rights-keller-frisco-transgender/">is currently under investigation</a> by the ACLU for discriminating against trans students. My teacher friends approach civil rights lessons with anxiety, fearful of triggering <a href="https://www.cnn.com/2023/05/23/us/florida-teacher-lgbtq-disney-movie-investigation/index.html#:~:text=The%20Hernando%20County%20School%20Board,by%20Jenna%20Barbee%2C%20the%20educator.">outraged reactions</a> from legislators and parents. We don‚Äôt live in a country where there is a consensus about what is harmful to children, so how could the government determine what‚Äôs appropriate for every kid?</p><p>People who are afraid of social media‚Äôs impact on kids, I've noticed, often quote a <a href="https://www.hhs.gov/sites/default/files/sg-youth-mental-health-social-media-advisory.pdf">recent advisory on the topic from the surgeon general</a> as evidence that kids should not have access to information online. But the most under-cited part of that report is actually the most important: There is a whole section that acknowledges LGBTQ+ youth actually <a href="https://www.nytimes.com/2023/05/24/upshot/social-media-lgbtq-benefits.html">have <em>better</em> outcomes</a> when they have access to social media and online communities.</p></div></div></div><div class="GridItem-buujkM fVLMby grid--item grid-layout__aside"><div class="StickyBoxWrapper-jfYBuk kNleGZ sticky-box"><div class="StickyBoxPrimary-dzWDWL cdhYoN sticky-box__primary"><div class="Container-bkChBi byNLHx"></div><div class="AdWrapper-dQtivb fZrssQ ad ad--rail"><div class="ad__slot ad__slot--rail" data-node-id="95yof7"></div></div><div class="ConsumerMarketingUnitThemedWrapper-iUTMTf jssHut consumer-marketing-unit consumer-marketing-unit--display-rail" role="presentation" aria-hidden="true"><div class="consumer-marketing-unit__slot consumer-marketing-unit__slot--display-rail"></div><div class="journey-unit"></div></div></div><div class="StickyBoxPlaceholder-grPmrg dxAvXx"></div></div></div></div><div data-testid="RowWrapper" class="RowWrapper-UmqTg HEhan full-bleed-ad row-mid-content-ad"><div class="StickyMidContentAdWrapper-fSBzwl drzyIa ad-stickymidcontent"><div class="AdWrapper-dQtivb fZrssQ ad ad--mid-content should-hold-space"><div class="ad__slot ad__slot--mid-content" data-node-id="kxr91f"></div></div></div></div><div class="GridWrapper-cAzTTK kHBDeH grid grid-margins grid-items-2 ArticlePageChunksGrid-hfxaau bjczjj grid-layout--adrail narrow wide-adrail"><div class="GridItem-buujkM stRKV grid--item grid-layout__content"><div class="BodyWrapper-kufPGa XtZXd body body__container article__body" data-journey-hook="client-content" data-testid="BodyWrapper"><div class="body__inner-container"><p>Simply put, queer and trans kids are <a href="https://www.tandfonline.com/doi/abs/10.1080/19359705.2013.777007">happier</a> and <a href="https://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/abs/pii/S014521341400283X">healthier</a> when they have access to supportive online groups, like the <a href="https://psycnet.apa.org/record/2019-13669-001">fandom communities</a> I found through fan fiction published on AO3. Last year, I attended the wedding of a friend I met in a comments section while gushing about our shared favorite fan fiction. We talked every day for years, and then I finally got to meet her in person, the day before she married the person she loved. Two other friends from that same community are married to each other now, and others have moved across the country to live together. All of us are queer and, in our teen years, had turned to fandom as a refuge, yearning for more inclusive stories and supportive communities we didn‚Äôt have in our day-to-day lives.</p><p>KOSA‚Äôs champions claim the amended bill, which was tweaked after vocal opposition, represents no threat to queer people and online communities like mine, but those of us who <a data-offer-url="https://www.tumblr.com/vergess/707882506784014336/you-wanna-talk-roots-lets-talk-about-how-most" class="external-link" data-event-click="{"element":"ExternalLink","outgoingURL":"https://www.tumblr.com/vergess/707882506784014336/you-wanna-talk-roots-lets-talk-about-how-most"}" href="https://www.tumblr.com/vergess/707882506784014336/you-wanna-talk-roots-lets-talk-about-how-most" rel="nofollow noopener" target="_blank">lived through</a> <a href="https://www.teenvogue.com/story/fosta-sesta-anti-sex-trafficking-bill">SESTA/FOSTA‚Äôs</a> impact on <a data-offer-url="https://www.aasect.org/position-fosta-sesta-and-its-impact-consensual-sex-work-and-chilling-sexual-speech" class="external-link" data-event-click="{"element":"ExternalLink","outgoingURL":"https://www.aasect.org/position-fosta-sesta-and-its-impact-consensual-sex-work-and-chilling-sexual-speech"}" href="https://www.aasect.org/position-fosta-sesta-and-its-impact-consensual-sex-work-and-chilling-sexual-speech" rel="nofollow noopener" target="_blank">sex education</a>, <a href="https://jezebel.com/i-m-hoping-it-won-t-decimate-my-income-tumblrs-porn-ba-1830879496">sex workers</a>, and <a href="https://www.engadget.com/2018-03-30-congress-just-legalized-sex-censorship-what-to-know.html">online content</a> know that just isn‚Äôt true. (And <a data-offer-url="https://twitter.com/evan_greer" class="external-link" data-event-click="{"element":"ExternalLink","outgoingURL":"https://twitter.com/evan_greer"}" href="https://twitter.com/evan_greer" rel="nofollow noopener" target="_blank">activists say the changes aren‚Äôt enough</a>.) SESTA/FOSTA, legislation that was supposed to help fight sex trafficking, <a href="https://hrlr.law.columbia.edu/files/2021/04/1084_Albert.pdf">not only failed to prevent trafficking and help survivors</a>, as research has shown, it decimated online communities and censored sex education content along the way. Much of this content was information many only had access to online, in places like <a data-offer-url="https://theconversation.com/why-tumblrs-ban-on-adult-content-is-bad-for-lgbtq-youth-108215" class="external-link" data-event-click="{"element":"ExternalLink","outgoingURL":"https://theconversation.com/why-tumblrs-ban-on-adult-content-is-bad-for-lgbtq-youth-108215"}" href="https://theconversation.com/why-tumblrs-ban-on-adult-content-is-bad-for-lgbtq-youth-108215" rel="nofollow noopener" target="_blank">Tumblr</a>, because of conservative parents and abstinence-only sex education we received at school.</p><p>Like SESTA/FOSTA, KOSA creates the aforementioned duty of care for social media companies, giving state attorneys general the power to sue sites like Instagram or Twitter if they put up content they deem ‚Äúharmful‚Äù for kids and teens. <a data-offer-url="https://www.eff.org/tossedout/tumblr-ban-adult-content" class="external-link" data-event-click="{"element":"ExternalLink","outgoingURL":"https://www.eff.org/tossedout/tumblr-ban-adult-content"}" href="https://www.eff.org/tossedout/tumblr-ban-adult-content" rel="nofollow noopener" target="_blank">With SESTA/FOSTA</a>, we saw that tech companies preferred to shut down <a href="https://www.wired.com/story/tiktok-abortion-content-censorship/">already-policed</a> content about reproductive justice, LGBTQ+ identities, and sex education than risk a lawsuit.</p><p>KOSA‚Äôs supporters might want to ignore the fact that it‚Äôs a censorship bill in disguise, but <a data-offer-url="https://www.heritage.org/technology/commentary/how-not-keep-children-safe-online" class="external-link" data-event-click="{"element":"ExternalLink","outgoingURL":"https://www.heritage.org/technology/commentary/how-not-keep-children-safe-online"}" href="https://www.heritage.org/technology/commentary/how-not-keep-children-safe-online" rel="nofollow noopener" target="_blank">the Heritage Foundation</a> is saying the quiet part <a data-offer-url="https://www.heritage.org/gender/commentary/how-big-tech-turns-kids-trans" class="external-link" data-event-click="{"element":"ExternalLink","outgoingURL":"https://www.heritage.org/gender/commentary/how-big-tech-turns-kids-trans"}" href="https://www.heritage.org/gender/commentary/how-big-tech-turns-kids-trans" rel="nofollow noopener" target="_blank">out loud</a>. The hard-line conservative organization has openly said KOSA will help them <a data-offer-url="https://twitter.com/ButNotTheCity/status/1661560827164471296" class="external-link" data-event-click="{"element":"ExternalLink","outgoingURL":"https://twitter.com/ButNotTheCity/status/1661560827164471296"}" href="https://twitter.com/ButNotTheCity/status/1661560827164471296" rel="nofollow noopener" target="_blank">censor</a> the content conservatives don‚Äôt want young people to have access to.¬†</p><p>The question is: Are <a href="https://www.vice.com/en/article/g5v9b7/lgbtq-youth-are-under-attack-why-are-democrats-pushing-a-bill-that-hurts-them-even-more">Democrats</a> going to hand them the keys to the kingdom? We have a choice in whether we fall for the rhetoric about kids' ‚Äúsafety‚Äù bills and watch in horror as the <a href="https://www.washingtonpost.com/nation/2022/12/14/texas-transgender-data-paxton/">Ken Paxtons</a> of the world weaponize them against our rights or fight KOSA with everything we‚Äôve got, pushing for <a href="https://www.wired.com/story/american-data-privacy-protection-act-adppa/">better tech bills</a> that would <a href="https://www.teenvogue.com/story/tik-tok-ban-young-people">actually protect young</a> people from the harms of Big Tech.</p><div data-attr-viewport-monitor="inline-recirc" class="inline-recirc-wrapper inline-recirc-observer-target-2 viewport-monitor-anchor"></div><p>If Congress wants to hold tech companies liable, there‚Äôs a ton of low-hanging fruit. The United States is <a href="https://www.nytimes.com/wirecutter/blog/state-of-privacy-laws-in-us/">embarrassingly behind</a> in data-privacy protections. That means that right now, it‚Äôs profitable for tech companies to spy on kids and teens and micro-target them with addictive and damaging content. If it wasn‚Äôt profitable, they would be pressured to move on to different, less harmful business models. There are other simpler options too: We could pass legislation to curb algorithmic harm, targeted advertising, and design features like endless scrolling.</p></div></div></div><div data-journey-hook="client-content" data-testid="BodyWrapper"><div class="body__inner-container"><p>In my day job, I‚Äôm a digital rights organizer who has been <a data-offer-url="https://www.badinternetbills.com/" class="external-link" data-event-click="{"element":"ExternalLink","outgoingURL":"https://www.badinternetbills.com/"}" href="https://www.badinternetbills.com/" rel="nofollow noopener" target="_blank">working against KOSA</a> for months. I talk to young people daily who are scared about the future of their online communities. Sure, fandom is partly about reading silly little stories written by our friends, but it represents so much more. When we can‚Äôt come out at home, we can lead safer, anonymous lives online. When queer stories have been physically <a href="https://www.teenvogue.com/story/students-protest-book-bans">pulled</a> from our library shelves, we can see ourselves in digital fiction written by people like us, for us. The panic about AO3 is not just about losing fan works, but about losing a lifeline in the midst of an <a href="https://www.cnn.com/2023/04/06/politics/anti-lgbtq-plus-state-bill-rights-dg/index.html">onslaught</a> of bigoted legislation.</p><p>When I meet KOSA supporters who claim to be ‚Äúprotecting the children,‚Äù I have to ask: Which children are we talking about? Because the children I know, the teenagers who email me every day with worries about KOSA, they live in fear of the future KOSA would create. I‚Äôll be damned if their future is an internet where the people who want to harm them most have the power to cut them off from their loved ones ‚Äî¬†even if those communities are found through a screen.</p><p><strong>Stay up-to-date with the politics team.</strong> <a href="https://www.teenvogue.com/newsletter/subscribe"><strong>Sign up for the</strong> <em><strong>Teen Vogue</strong></em> But the Kids Online Safety Act (KOSA) is the real threat.","head.keywords":"internet,transgender rights,trans,lgbtq rights,lgbtq youth,community,social media,fandom,u.s. government,congress,politics op-ed","head.og.type":"article","head.robots":"index, follow, max-image-preview:large","head.title":"Archive of Our Own Survived a Cyberattack, But Will It Survive Congress? | Teen Vogue","tenant":"teen-vogue","head.social.title":"This Bill Threatens Access to LGBTQ+ Online Communities","head.social.description":"The Kids Online Safety Act is a censorship bill in disguise.","head.promo.dek":"The Kids Online Safety Act is a censorship bill in disguise.","head.social.opinion":"false","head.jsonld":[{"@context":"http:\u002F\u002Fschema.org","@type":"NewsArticle","articleBody":"One day in mid-July, the revered fan fiction site Archive of Our Own (AO3), a bottomless repository for stories set in thousands of fictional worlds, suddenly went dark. AO3 was inaccessible for more than 24 hours. The volunteer-run site, we later learned, had been targeted by cyberattackers who reportedly had religious and political motivations for aiming to take down the site.\nI‚Äôve been an AO3 reader for over 10 years, and this isn‚Äôt the first outage I‚Äôve experienced. But this one felt different. Not only was it longer than usual, it was apparently prompted, in part, by hatred for queer people.\nA day later, AO3 was back online, but concerns have lingered: What would happen if fan communities, especially queer fandoms that are lifelines for young LGBTQ+ people, ceased to exist? And it turns out, one of the most worrisome threats facing sites like AO3 isn‚Äôt a small outfit of cyberattackers, it‚Äôs the United States government.\nRight now there are a handful of bills being rushed through Congress in the 11th hour before August recess that could permanently damage the ability of AO3 to reach its audience. The main threat is the Kids Online Safety Act (KOSA). Framed as ‚Äúprotecting children,‚Äù KOSA creates a ‚Äúduty of care‚Äù that requires apps and websites to ‚Äúprevent and mitigate‚Äù harms to children, like anxiety and depression, their products might cause. If the app or website doesn‚Äôt take steps to mitigate those harms, usually through removing content, it can be held liable.\nProtecting children from harmful content with Big Tech taking the fall may sound great, until you consider who will have the power to decide what content is harmful ‚Äî and, therefore, what content is removed. KOSA authorizes state attorneys general to be the ultimate arbiters of what is good or bad for kids. If a state attorney general asserts that information about gender-affirming care or abortion care could cause a child depression or anxiety, they could sue an app or website for not removing that content.\nTo prevent that liability, the app or website could proactively remove content that a conservative attorney general might think is bad for kids. But a lot of attorneys general think legitimate content is bad for kids.\nI live in Texas, where our attorney general, Ken Paxton, has called gender-affirming health care child abuse. Some Texas lawmakers want to make it illegal for abortion funds to have websites. The school district I grew up in is currently under investigation by the ACLU for discriminating against trans students. My teacher friends approach civil rights lessons with anxiety, fearful of triggering outraged reactions from legislators and parents. We don‚Äôt live in a country where there is a consensus about what is harmful to children, so how could the government determine what‚Äôs appropriate for every kid?\nPeople who are afraid of social media‚Äôs impact on kids, I've noticed, often quote a recent advisory on the topic from the surgeon general as evidence that kids should not have access to information online. But the most under-cited part of that report is actually the most important: There is a whole section that acknowledges LGBTQ+ youth actually have better outcomes when they have access to social media and online communities.\nSimply put, queer and trans kids are happier and healthier when they have access to supportive online groups, like the fandom communities I found through fan fiction published on AO3. Last year, I attended the wedding of a friend I met in a comments section while gushing about our shared favorite fan fiction. We talked every day for years, and then I finally got to meet her in person, the day before she married the person she loved. Two other friends from that same community are married to each other now, and others have moved across the country to live together. All of us are queer and, in our teen years, had turned to fandom as a refuge, yearning for more inclusive stories and supportive communities we didn‚Äôt have in our day-to-day lives.\nKOSA‚Äôs champions claim the amended bill, which was tweaked after vocal opposition, represents no threat to queer people and online communities like mine, but those of us who lived through SESTA\u002FFOSTA‚Äôs impact on sex education, sex workers, and online content know that just isn‚Äôt true. (And activists say the changes aren‚Äôt enough.) SESTA\u002FFOSTA, legislation that was supposed to help fight sex trafficking, not only failed to prevent trafficking and help survivors, as research has shown, it decimated online communities and censored sex education content along the way. Much of this content was information many only had access to online, in places like Tumblr, because of conservative parents and abstinence-only sex education we received at school.\nLike SESTA\u002FFOSTA, KOSA creates the aforementioned duty of care for social media companies, giving state attorneys general the power to sue sites like Instagram or Twitter if they put up content they deem ‚Äúharmful‚Äù for kids and teens. With SESTA\u002FFOSTA, we saw that tech companies preferred to shut down already-policed content about reproductive justice, LGBTQ+ identities, and sex education than risk a lawsuit.\nKOSA‚Äôs supporters might want to ignore the fact that it‚Äôs a censorship bill in disguise, but the Heritage Foundation is saying the quiet part out loud. The hard-line conservative organization has openly said KOSA will help them censor the content conservatives don‚Äôt want young people to have access to.\nThe question is: Are Democrats going to hand them the keys to the kingdom? We have a choice in whether we fall for the rhetoric about kids' ‚Äúsafety‚Äù bills and watch in horror as the Ken Paxtons of the world weaponize them against our rights or fight KOSA with everything we‚Äôve got, pushing for better tech bills that would actually protect young people from the harms of Big Tech.\nIf Congress wants to hold tech companies liable, there‚Äôs a ton of low-hanging fruit. The United States is embarrassingly behind in data-privacy protections. That means that right now, it‚Äôs profitable for tech companies to spy on kids and teens and micro-target them with addictive and damaging content. If it wasn‚Äôt profitable, they would be pressured to move on to different, less harmful business models. There are other simpler options too: We could pass legislation to curb algorithmic harm, targeted advertising, and design features like endless scrolling.\nIn my day job, I‚Äôm a digital rights organizer who has been working against KOSA for months. I talk to young people daily who are scared about the future of their online communities. Sure, fandom is partly about reading silly little stories written by our friends, but it represents so much more. When we can‚Äôt come out at home, we can lead safer, anonymous lives online. When queer stories have been physically pulled from our library shelves, we can see ourselves in digital fiction written by people like us, for us. The panic about AO3 is not just about losing fan works, but about losing a lifeline in the midst of an onslaught of bigoted legislation.\nWhen I meet KOSA supporters who claim to be ‚Äúprotecting the children,‚Äù I have to ask: Which children are we talking about? Because the children I know, the teenagers who email me every day with worries about KOSA, they live in fear of the future KOSA would create. I‚Äôll be damned if their future is an internet where the people who want to harm them most have the power to cut them off from their loved ones ‚Äî¬†even if those communities are found through a screen.\nStay up-to-date with the politics team. readabilityObject.title: Archive of Our Own Survived a Cyberattack, But Will It Survive Congress?
readabilityObject.content:
One day in mid-July, the revered fan fiction site Archive of Our Own (AO3), a bottomless repository for stories set in thousands of fictional worlds, suddenly went dark. AO3 was inaccessible for more than 24 hours. The volunteer-run site, we later learned, had been targeted by cyberattackers who reportedly had religious and political motivations for aiming to take down the site. 

I‚Äôve been an AO3 reader for over 10 years, and this isn‚Äôt the first outage I‚Äôve experienced. But this one felt different. Not only was it longer than usual, it was apparently prompted, in part, by hatred for queer people. 

A day later, AO3 was back online, but concerns have lingered: What would happen if fan communities, especially queer fandoms that are lifelines for young LGBTQ+ people, ceased to exist? And it turns out, one of the most worrisome threats facing sites like AO3 isn‚Äôt a small outfit of cyberattackers, it‚Äôs the United States government.

Right now there are a handful of bills being rushed through Congress in the 11th hour before August recess that could permanently damage the ability of AO3 to reach its audience. The main threat is the Kids Online Safety Act (KOSA). Framed as ‚Äúprotecting children,‚Äù KOSA creates a ‚Äúduty of care‚Äù that requires apps and websites to ‚Äúprevent and mitigate‚Äù harms to children, like anxiety and depression, their products might cause. If the app or website doesn‚Äôt take steps to mitigate those harms, usually through removing content, it can be held liable.

Protecting children from harmful content with Big Tech taking the fall may sound great, until you consider who will have the power to decide what content is harmful ‚Äî and, therefore, what content is removed. KOSA authorizes state attorneys general to be the ultimate arbiters of what is good or bad for kids. If a state attorney general asserts that information about gender-affirming care or abortion care could cause a child depression or anxiety, they could sue an app or website for not removing that content. 

To prevent that liability, the app or website could proactively remove content that a conservative attorney general might think is bad for kids. But a lot of attorneys general think legitimate content is bad for kids.

I live in Texas, where our attorney general, Ken Paxton, has called gender-affirming health care child abuse. Some Texas lawmakers want to make it illegal for abortion funds to have websites. The school district I grew up in is currently under investigation by the ACLU for discriminating against trans students. My teacher friends approach civil rights lessons with anxiety, fearful of triggering outraged reactions from legislators and parents. We don‚Äôt live in a country where there is a consensus about what is harmful to children, so how could the government determine what‚Äôs appropriate for every kid?

People who are afraid of social media‚Äôs impact on kids, I've noticed, often quote a recent advisory on the topic from the surgeon general as evidence that kids should not have access to information online. But the most under-cited part of that report is actually the most important: There is a whole section that acknowledges LGBTQ+ youth actually have better outcomes when they have access to social media and online communities.

Simply put, queer and trans kids are happier and healthier when they have access to supportive online groups, like the fandom communities I found through fan fiction published on AO3. Last year, I attended the wedding of a friend I met in a comments section while gushing about our shared favorite fan fiction. We talked every day for years, and then I finally got to meet her in person, the day before she married the person she loved. Two other friends from that same community are married to each other now, and others have moved across the country to live together. All of us are queer and, in our teen years, had turned to fandom as a refuge, yearning for more inclusive stories and supportive communities we didn‚Äôt have in our day-to-day lives.

KOSA‚Äôs champions claim the amended bill, which was tweaked after vocal opposition, represents no threat to queer people and online communities like mine, but those of us who lived through SESTA/FOSTA‚Äôs impact on sex education, sex workers, and online content know that just isn‚Äôt true. (And activists say the changes aren‚Äôt enough.) SESTA/FOSTA, legislation that was supposed to help fight sex trafficking, not only failed to prevent trafficking and help survivors, as research has shown, it decimated online communities and censored sex education content along the way. Much of this content was information many only had access to online, in places like Tumblr, because of conservative parents and abstinence-only sex education we received at school.

Like SESTA/FOSTA, KOSA creates the aforementioned duty of care for social media companies, giving state attorneys general the power to sue sites like Instagram or Twitter if they put up content they deem ‚Äúharmful‚Äù for kids and teens. With SESTA/FOSTA, we saw that tech companies preferred to shut down already-policed content about reproductive justice, LGBTQ+ identities, and sex education than risk a lawsuit.

KOSA‚Äôs supporters might want to ignore the fact that it‚Äôs a censorship bill in disguise, but the Heritage Foundation is saying the quiet part out loud. The hard-line conservative organization has openly said KOSA will help them censor the content conservatives don‚Äôt want young people to have access to. 

The question is: Are Democrats going to hand them the keys to the kingdom? We have a choice in whether we fall for the rhetoric about kids' ‚Äúsafety‚Äù bills and watch in horror as the Ken Paxtons of the world weaponize them against our rights or fight KOSA with everything we‚Äôve got, pushing for better tech bills that would actually protect young people from the harms of Big Tech.

If Congress wants to hold tech companies liable, there‚Äôs a ton of low-hanging fruit. The United States is embarrassingly behind in data-privacy protections. That means that right now, it‚Äôs profitable for tech companies to spy on kids and teens and micro-target them with addictive and damaging content. If it wasn‚Äôt profitable, they would be pressured to move on to different, less harmful business models. There are other simpler options too: We could pass legislation to curb algorithmic harm, targeted advertising, and design features like endless scrolling.

In my day job, I‚Äôm a digital rights organizer who has been working against KOSA for months. I talk to young people daily who are scared about the future of their online communities. Sure, fandom is partly about reading silly little stories written by our friends, but it represents so much more. When we can‚Äôt come out at home, we can lead safer, anonymous lives online. When queer stories have been physically pulled from our library shelves, we can see ourselves in digital fiction written by people like us, for us. The panic about AO3 is not just about losing fan works, but about losing a lifeline in the midst of an onslaught of bigoted legislation.

When I meet KOSA supporters who claim to be ‚Äúprotecting the children,‚Äù I have to ask: Which children are we talking about? Because the children I know, the teenagers who email me every day with worries about KOSA, they live in fear of the future KOSA would create. I‚Äôll be damned if their future is an internet where the people who want to harm them most have the power to cut them off from their loved ones ‚Äî even if those communities are found through a screen.

Stay up-to-date with the politics team. Sign up for the Teen Vogue Take

But the most under-cited part of that report is actually the most important: There is a whole section that acknowledges LGBTQ+ youth actually have better outcomes when they have access to social media and online communities.
Simply put, queer and trans kids are happier and healthier when they have access to supportive online groups, like the fandom communities I found through fan fiction published on AO3. Last year, I attended the wedding of a friend I met in a comments section while gushing about our shared favorite fan fiction. We talked every day for years, and then I finally got to meet her in person, the day before she married the person she loved. Two other friends from that same community are married to each other now, and others have moved across the country to live together. All of us are queer and, in our teen years, had turned to fandom as a refuge, yearning for more inclusive stories and supportive communities we didn‚Äôt have in our day-to-day lives.
KOSA‚Äôs champions claim the amended bill, which was tweaked after vocal opposition, represents no threat to queer people and online communities like mine, but those of us who lived through SESTA/FOSTA‚Äôs impact on sex education, sex workers, and online content know that just isn‚Äôt true. (And activists say the changes aren‚Äôt enough.) SESTA/FOSTA, legislation that was supposed to help fight sex trafficking, not only failed to prevent trafficking and help survivors, as research has shown, it decimated online communities and censored sex education content along the way. Much of this content was information many only had access to online, in places like Tumblr, because of conservative parents and abstinence-only sex education we received at school.
Like SESTA/FOSTA, KOSA creates the aforementioned duty of care for social media companies, giving state attorneys general the power to sue sites like Instagram or Twitter if they put up content they deem ‚Äúharmful‚Äù for kids and teens. With SESTA/FOSTA, we saw that tech companies preferred to shut down already-policed content about reproductive justice, LGBTQ+ identities, and sex education than risk a lawsuit.
KOSA‚Äôs supporters might want to ignore the fact that it‚Äôs a censorship bill in disguise, but the Heritage Foundation is saying the quiet part out loud. The hard-line conservative organization has openly said KOSA will help them censor the content conservatives don‚Äôt want young people to have access to.
The question is: Are Democrats going to hand them the keys to the kingdom? We have a choice in whether we fall for the rhetoric about kids' ‚Äúsafety‚Äù bills and watch in horror as the Ken Paxtons of the world weaponize them against our rights or fight KOSA with everything we‚Äôve got, pushing for better tech bills that would actually protect young people from the harms of Big Tech.
If Congress wants to hold tech companies liable, there‚Äôs a ton of low-hanging fruit. The United States is embarrassingly behind in data-privacy protections. That means that right now, it‚Äôs profitable for tech companies to spy on kids and teens and micro-target them with addictive and damaging content. If it wasn‚Äôt profitable, they would be pressured to move on to different, less harmful business models. There are other simpler options too: We could pass legislation to curb algorithmic harm, targeted advertising, and design features like endless scrolling.
In my day job, I‚Äôm a digital rights organizer who has been working against KOSA for months. I talk to young people daily who are scared about the future of their online communities. Sure, fandom is partly about reading silly little stories written by our friends, but it represents so much more. When we can‚Äôt come out at home, we can lead safer, anonymous lives online. When queer stories have been physically pulled from our library shelves, we can see ourselves in digital fiction written by people like us, for us. The panic about AO3 is not just about losing fan works, but about losing a lifeline in the midst of an onslaught of bigoted legislation.
When I meet KOSA supporters who claim to be ‚Äúprotecting the children,‚Äù I have to ask: Which children are we talking about? Because the children I know, the teenagers who email me every day with worries about KOSA, they live in fear of the future KOSA would create. I‚Äôll be damned if their future is an internet where the people who want to harm them most have the power to cut them off from their loved ones ‚Äî¬†even if those communities are found through a screen.
